[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: SeedEncoding::from_str()] [Input validation bypass] Can an attacker exploit case-sensitivity issues by providing mixed-case encoding strings (e.g., 'BcS', 'HeX') that bypass validation but produce different seed encodings, leading to address collisions with legitimate resource accounts? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: SeedEncoding::from_str()] [Type confusion] Does the parser properly handle Unicode normalization attacks where visually identical characters (e.g., Cyrillic 'Ð°' vs Latin 'a') could be used to bypass the encoding validation and produce unexpected seed encodings? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: SeedEncoding::from_str()] [Parsing bypass] Can an attacker inject whitespace, null bytes, or control characters within the encoding string that bypass the to_lowercase() check but alter the parsed encoding type, causing address derivation mismatches? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: SeedEncoding::from_str()] [Error handling] Does the error message expose sensitive information about valid encoding types that could help attackers enumerate supported encodings for targeted attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: SeedEncoding::from_str()] [UTF-8 variant handling] Are all UTF-8 string variants ('utf8', 'utf-8', 'utf_8') properly canonicalized to the same encoding, or can subtle differences lead to different seed byte representations causing address mismatches? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [BCS encoding attack] When using BCS encoding, can an attacker craft seeds where the BCS length prefix (first byte) creates ambiguity with other encoding schemes, allowing address collision with accounts created using different encodings? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [BCS serialization] Does BCS encoding of empty strings or strings with special lengths create predictable patterns that attackers could exploit to generate colliding resource account addresses? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [BCS overflow] Can an attacker provide extremely long seed strings that cause BCS encoding to produce oversized byte vectors, potentially triggering integer overflows in downstream address derivation or memory exhaustion? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [BCS determinism] Is BCS encoding guaranteed to be deterministic across different Rust compiler versions and platforms, or could platform-specific differences lead to different addresses for the same logical seed? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [Hex parsing bypass] Can an attacker provide hex strings without '0x' prefix that get interpreted differently by HexEncodedBytes::from_str(), causing address derivation to fail or produce unexpected results? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [Hex case sensitivity] Does hex decoding properly handle both uppercase and lowercase hex characters uniformly, or can case variations lead to different byte representations and address collisions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [Hex padding] Can an attacker exploit missing or extra leading zeros in hex strings (e.g., '0x01' vs '0x1') to create seeds that decode to different byte vectors, enabling address manipulation attacks? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [Hex length validation] Are odd-length hex strings properly rejected, or can they be decoded into ambiguous byte representations that could cause address derivation inconsistencies? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [Hex overflow] Can an attacker provide extremely long hex strings (e.g., megabytes) that cause the HexEncodedBytes parser to allocate excessive memory or trigger DoS conditions during address derivation? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [UTF-8 normalization] Does UTF-8 encoding handle Unicode normalization (NFC vs NFD) consistently, or can attackers create visually identical seeds that produce different byte representations and address collisions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [UTF-8 invalid sequences] Can an attacker inject invalid UTF-8 sequences or replacement characters (U+FFFD) that get normalized during as_bytes() conversion, altering the seed bytes and causing address mismatches? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [UTF-8 BOM] Does UTF-8 encoding properly strip Byte Order Marks (BOM) from seeds, or can attackers inject BOMs to create different byte representations for the same logical seed string? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/account/derive_resource_account.rs] [Function: ResourceAccountSeed::seed()] [UTF-8 null bytes] Can an attacker embed null bytes within UTF-8 seeds that get preserved in as_bytes(), allowing truncation attacks or address derivation manipulation? (High)
